ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] H3.0 ToeThread.recoverableProblem()  - crawler crashes

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] H3.0 ToeThread.recoverableProblem()  - crawler
 crashes
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=Lsm0Oe1FiF2IZCQbxZtOxBgdq8OBhv-7x3QUJ9qixfPq
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

Pranay -

You should definitely try to move to 3.1. There have been many 
significant fixes, including some which resolve heap OutOfMemoryErrors, 
and the required configuration adaptations shouldn't be too difficult.

(Also: while it's probably *not* related to your problem, the class 
FairGenericObjectPool which appears in your example error stack was 
eliminated from the master development branch in August 2010.)

The stack you forward is probably an indicator of a secondary effect, 
rather than the primary problem.  It says that a thread was unable to 
get one of the 'writer' instances (one per open file, usually only 1-5). 
Essentially that means some other thread either hung or crashed so badly 
while using a writer instance that the instance was never returned to 
the pool for use by other threads.

So to figure out what really/originally went wrong, the key places to 
look would be either a current thread-report (to find other threads 
still holding writers), or closely reviewing the alerts/heritrix_out.log 
for earlier errors during WARC-writing (that could have been severe the 
writer was not cleanly returned).

However, since you mention running out of java heap space, it's 
important to note that once an OutOfMemoryError has occurred at some 
arbitrary place, it's very possible the running crawl/heap is 
unrecoverably damaged. We attempt to retain as much state as posible for 
diagnosis, and sometimes you can even try to continue, but it's best to 
consider that run as 'crashed' and only use what's still running for 
investigation of the problem. An OOME in earlier WARC-writing could 
explain the later 'Timeout' stack you've received.

If you can't quickly move to the latest 3.1 and each crawl is truly a 
fresh restart, then ensuring that you restart the JVM each day could 
help isolate later crawls from any lingering memory effects from the 
earlier, completed crawls.

- Gordon

On 1/3/12 6:18 AM, Pranay Pandey wrote:
>
>
>
> I am running a handful of jobs - each one runs for about 20 hrs a day,
> terminated and restarted again the next day.
> I am noticing that while everything runs smooth for a while (a week or
> so), after that, some of the object fetch attempts run into indefinite
> cycles.
> This leads to memory hog, overrunning java heap space and ultimately the
> crawler crashes.
>
> Below is a portion of the log. I still am using H3.0.0
>
> Any directions?
>
> 2011-12-07 05:09:13.721 SEVERE thread-1370
> org.archive.crawler.framework.ToeThread.recoverableProblem() Problem
> java.util.NoSuchElementException: Timeout waiting for idle object
> occured when trying to process
> 'http://media.xyz.com/photogallery/photo/10211058-small.jpg' at step
> ABOUT_TO_BEGIN_PROCESSOR in
>
> java.util.NoSuchElementException: Timeout waiting for idle object
> at
> org.apache.commons.pool.impl.FairGenericObjectPool.borrowObject(FairGenericObjectPool.java:247)
> at org.archive.io.WriterPool.borrowFile(WriterPool.java:135)
> at
> org.archive.modules.writer.WARCWriterProcessor.write(WARCWriterProcessor.java:204)
> at
> org.archive.modules.writer.WARCWriterProcessor.innerProcessResult(WARCWriterProcessor.java:188)
> at org.archive.modules.Processor.process(Processor.java:144)
> at org.archive.modules.ProcessorChain.process(ProcessorChain.java:131)
> at org.archive.modules.DispositionChain.process(DispositionChain.java:55)
> at org.archive.crawler.framework.ToeThread.run(ToeThread.java:150)
> not politeness-calc
>
>
> Thanks,
> Pranay
>
>
>
